questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with a history of intense itching in the elbows and knees. The examination findings are shown in the given image. Similar lesions are also present on his knees. He also says that whenever he starts eating whole wheat in his diet, he has severe diarrhea, abdominal pain, and bloating sensation. The doctor takes samples from the lesion and perilesional skin and sends them for direct immunofluorescence. It is likely to show the deposition of which of the following antibodies?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is dermatitis herpetiformis. There are multiple erythematous papules over the elbows and knees, and the history of the patient suggests that he has gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Direct immunofluorescence will show the deposition of IgA antibodies.

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely pruritic, skin condition associated with gluten‐sensitive enteropathy. It can also be associated with autoimmune thyroid disease. It is associated with HLA‐DQ2.

It typically appears in the 4th decade, and the patients present with itching and rash, most typically over the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. They may also have symptoms associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathies, like bloating, diarrhea and other gastrointestinal complaints.

On examination, multiple erythematous macules and papules can be seen over the extensor aspects. They appear symmetrical and heal without scarring. The oral cavity may show mucosal abnormalities and enamel pits.

Diagnosis can be made by clinical features, histopathology, direct immunofluorescence testing, and serology.

The histopathology of an intact vesicle in dermatitis herpetiformis will show subepidermal blister formation with neutrophils located at the tips of the dermal papillae. Perivascular infiltrates can also be seen.

Direct immunofluorescence can be done to the skin samples taken from the lesion and perilesional skin. It will show the deposition of IgA antibodies in the papillary dermis in a granular or fibrillar pattern. Complement 3 may also be found along with the IgA deposits.

Serology many show the presence of IgA anti-endomysial autoantibodies that target epidermal transglutaminase 3.

Management- Having a gluten-free diet is the mainstay of treatment. Because the response to a gluten-free diet takes time, dapsone is used for medium to short term in the treatment of the symptoms. 

The below image shows the deposition of IgA antibodies in the papillary dermis in a granular pattern. These antibodies are epidermal transglutaminase 3.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with severe itching and skin lesions as shown below. On examination, multiple red and yellow crusts are seen. Nikolsky's sign is negative. There is no mucosal involvement. There is no history of allergy to gluten. Immunofluorescence microscopy shows subepidermal split and deposition of IgG antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts bullous pemphigoid. 

Bullous pemphigoid is a subepidermal immunobullous disorder. It occurs due to the production of autoantibodies (IgG) against BP180 (BPAG2) and BP230 (BPAG1) antigens on hemidesmosomes.

The patients are usually elderly and present with itching and tense bullae, mainly on the flexural areas and the abdomen. These blisters might rupture and give rise to hemorrhagic or yellow crusts. Mucosal membrane involvement is rare in this disease. Most of the lesions heal without a scar. Since these bullae are subepidermal, pressure over the lesions does not separate the epidermis from the dermis (Nikolsky sign is negative).

Immunofluorescent microscopy will show the presence of subepidermal split and deposition of IgG antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction. Histopathology will show the presence of subepidermal bullae with eosinophils.

It is mainly treated with corticosteroids. Other drugs used are azathioprine, dapsone, doxycycline, etc.

The below image shows linear IgG deposits at the dermo-epidermal junction seen in bullous pemphigoid.

Other options:

Option A- Pemphigus vulgaris is an intraepidermal immunobullous disease. It occurs commonly between the 4th to 6th decade. These present with flaccid blisters. Firm pressure over the lesion separates the epidermis from the dermis. Nikolsky's sign is positive. Mucosal involvement will be seen in the form of buccal and palatal erosions.

Option C- Dermatitis herpetiformis typically appears in the 4th decade, and the patients present with itching and rash, most typically over the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. The majority of the patients have symptoms related to gluten-sensitive enteropathies, like bloating, diarrhea, and other gastrointestinal complaints. Immunofluorescence microscopy will show the deposition of IgA antibodies in the papillary dermis in a granular or fibrillar pattern. Complement 3 may also be found along with the IgA deposits.

Option D- Impetigo herpetiformis is a type of generalized pustular psoriasis (GPP) occurring in pregnancy. It presents with flexural erythema, pustules, and periumbilical pustulation, and can be associated with fever, tetany, and hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A young man presents with a leg lesion as shown in the image below. On examination, the lesions are painful and the edges are well-demarcated and raised. He also complains of blisters over his body. He is otherwise normal and does not have any other disease. This infection is most likely to be caused by which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of erythematous skin lesions with well-demarcated borders. The edge is raised. This is the hallmark of erysipelas. In immunocompetent patients, it is caused by group A Streptococcus.

Erysipelas is a bacterial infection of the superficial dermis.

Causative organisms:

  • Group A Streptococcus - Common cause
  • Group B Streptococcus - May cause infection under the age of 3 months and pelvic erysipelas after surgery
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b - causes facial cellulitis

Patients will have erythema, heat, swelling, and pain or tenderness over the affected site. The edge of the lesion is well-demarcated and raised. Blistering can also be seen. The most common site is the leg followed by the face. It can also affect the ear. Involvement of the ear is called Milian's ear sign.

It is treated with antibiotics like flucloxacillin, clarithromycin, clindamycin, and benzylpenicillin.

Another infection similar to erysipelas is cellulitis. It is the infection of loose connective tissue. It is also commonly caused by group A Streptococcus. Important differentiating features are

  • The edges of the lesions are diffuse in cellulitis
  • The ear is not involved as there is no subcutaneous tissue and deeper dermis in the ear.

Other options:

Staphylococcus aureus infection is caused when there is a breach in the continuity of epithelium or mucosa manifesting as folliculitis, impetigo, secondary infection of underlying inflam­matory skin diseases (dermatitis), boils/abscesses, or cellulitis.

Haemophilus influenzae type b is an important cause of facial cellulitis in young children especially up to the age of 2 years

Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

questions.text: A  shepherd developed a skin lesion on his left index finger as shown in the image below. He says that it initially started as a small reddish lesion, and now it has enlarged to look like this. On further questioning, he says that his sheep are also having some lesions on their skin. Apart from this, he complains of mild fever. On examination, there is pain and enlargement of the left axillary lymph nodes. Identify the correct statement regarding the diagnosis.

choices.text: Face is the commonest site of lesion

questions.solution:
The given image and clinical scenario are suggestive of orf infection. It is also called ecthyma contagiosum. It is caused by parapoxvirus.

It is seen in individuals working with sheep and goats. The lesion develops 5–6 days (range 3–10 days) after contact with an infected animal or animal carcass. A small, firm, red, or reddish-blue papule appears at the skin site of contact and enlarges into a hemorrhagic pustule or bulla.

The most common sites of orf lesions are on the hands and forearms. Less commonly it can also occur on the face, axilla, and genital regions. The lesions heal after 3–6 weeks.

Microscopy will show ballooning degeneration of keratinocytes in the epidermis with eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions.

An important complication of this infection is erythema multiforme. It usually presents 2-3 weeks after the orf infection. It can also precipitate immunobullous disease.

Treatment is not usually necessary. Secondary bacterial infections should be treated appropriately. Large exophytic lesions require surgical removal. Recurrent or persistent lesions require additional therapies like cryotherapy, idoxuridine, imiquimod, or cidofovir cream.

Note- Erythema marginatum is a manifestation of rheumatic fever. It is a nonpruritic, serpiginous, erythematous macule or papule commonly present on the trunk and upper limbs. It rapidly spreads.

Below image shows erythema marginatum

Related Pearl: Tzanck Smear in Dermatology

The Tzanck smear, introduced by the Frenchman Tzanck, is a simple to perform, inexpensive bed side cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular and bullous diseases, in particular herpes.

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

Preparation of Tzanck smear:

  • Viral infections and Blistering disorders - fresh vesicle or intact blister is de-roofed and base is scraped 
  • Suspected tumors - any crust should be removed from ulcerated tumors, and non-ulcerated tumors should be incised with a sharp, pointed scalpel and sample is then obtained with either a blunt scalpel or a small curette
  • The smear should preferably be fixed immediately using Formol-Zenker solution since significant artifacts can result from drying.
  • Tzanck smear can be stained by a variety of methods, most commonly by Giemsa stain. Other stains used are hematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou and toluidine blue. 

Results in Tzanck Smear:

A typical Tzanck cell is a large round keratinocyte with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. The basophilic staining is deeper peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells) due to the cytoplasm's tendency to get condensed at the periphery, leading to a perinuclear halo.

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. He says that he first noticed it around 4 months back and is worried about the new lesions that are appearing at sites of injury. The lesions appear white on Woods lamp examination. This condition occurs due to
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of localized depigmented macules showing Koebner phenomenon, which are indicative of vitiligo, a condition that occurs due to a lack of melanocytes in the basal layer of the epidermis.

Vitiligo presents with localized depigmentation that occurs due to a progressive loss in the melanocytes. It is classified into segmental vitiligo, which appears as unilateral maculae in a segmented or band-shaped pattern, or non-segmental vitiligo, which appears as bilateral maculae distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body. The lesions become apparent between 20-30 years of age. 

Hypopigmented macules in vitiligo are commonly found in the hips, dorsum of the hands/fingers, feet, elbows, knees, and ankle areas. These are the areas of repeated friction. Rarely there may be complete vitiligo or vitiligo universalis, or trichrome vitiligo where there are areas of depigmentation, and hyperpigmentation, along with the normal skin. Koebner phenomenon is the development of lesions at the site of trauma on the uninvolved skin.

Several autoimmune conditions can be associated with vitiligo. They are thyroid disease (hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism), pernicious anemia, Addison's disease, diabetes, and hypoparathyroidism.

Under the Wood's lamp examination, the depigmented areas emit a bright blue-white fluorescence and appear sharply demarcated.

Treatment involves cosmetic camouflage and sunscreen. Topical corticosteroids are the first line of treatment. Topical calcineurin inhibitors like pimecrolimus and tacrolimus are also used. Psoralen photochemotherapy, khellin, and selective ultraviolet B therapy are second-line treatments. Surgical grafting can be used in refractory cases, where melanocytes from a normal pigmented area are transferred to non-pigmented areas. In patients with extensive vitiligo where only a few pigmented areas are left, depigmentation can be done.

Other diseases with decreased pigmentation are:

Piebaldism: commonly presents with a white V-shaped forelock. It is caused due to the impaired migration of melanocytes to the skin.

Albinism is a genetic disorder characterized by generalized depigmentation of the skin, hair, and eye, caused by a deficiency in melanin biosynthesis.

Idiopathic guttate hypomelanosis (IGH) is an acquired leukoderma caused due to decreased melanocytes and melanin.

Postinflammatory hypomelanosis and pityriasis alba occur due to an impaired transfer of melanin to the keratinocytes.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple papules on elbows having a follicular distribution. This is known as phrynoderma or "toad-skin" which can occur due to the deficiency of vitamin A, B complex, riboflavin, vitamin C, vitamin E, and essential fatty acids. Options 2, 3, 5, and 6 are correct.

It manifests as groups of papules with a central keratotic plug. The commonest sites are elbows and knees. They are present around the follicles and give the skin a rough texture.

Treatment involves the correction of poor diet and administration of a multivitamin preparation containing vitamin A.

Other options

 Iron deficiency leads to anemia. Dermatological manifestations of iron deficiency are:

  • Brittle nails with longitudinal ridges- in moderate deficiency
  • Koilonychia- spoon-shaped nails in severe deficiency. It commonly affects third and fourth nails.
  • Atrophic tongue, glossodynia (pain in the tongue), aphthous and angular stomatitis.
  • Brittle, dry, and lustreless hair

Deficiency of vitamin D and calcium results in poor mineralization of bone leading to rickets. There may be fraying and widening of the metaphysis, prominent costochondral joints (rachitic rosary), craniotabes, bowing of the lower extremities, frontal bossing, scoliosis, fractures, and dental anomalies. The only cutaneous manifestation of vitamin D deficiency is alopecia.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with the following itchy lesions on the extensor aspect of the elbow and trunk. When the doctor scratched the lesions, the scale formation increased, followed by the appearance of a glossy red membrane, that on removal revealed some pinpoint bleeding spots. All other features mentioned below can be found in this patient except
questions.solution:
The given image shows a red scaly plaque with silvery-white fine scales, and the lesion on scratching shows Auspitz's sign on scratching. These features are suggestive of psoriasis in the patient. Pautrier's microabscess is a feature of mycosis fungoides.

Psoriasis is a chronic, inflammatory, and proliferative condition of the skin that also involves various organ manifestations. Several factors play a role in the development of the disease. They can be streptococcal infections, medications like beta-blockers, non‐steroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and angiotensin‐converting enzymes, alcohol abuse, cigarette smoking, and psychological stress.

Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis and is seen in 80-90% of patients. The peak in occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash. The lesions are red and scaly and have well demarcation from the normal skin. They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone, which is called the Woronoff ring (option B). They commonly appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

When the lesions are scratched, the scaling increases initially. The successive removal of scales usually reveals an underlying smooth, glossy red membrane. This membrane, when removed, shows small bleeding points. This finding is called Auspitz’s sign.

The nails may be involved in psoriasis. The nails grow quickly in patients with psoriasis. Involvement of nail matrix disease leads to pits (option D), ridges, and grooves of the nail plate. Involvement of the nail bed causes subungual oil drops (option C), subungual hyperkeratosis, and distal onycholysis.

Histopathology will show the presence of hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, the disappearance of the granular layer, and epidermal hyperplasia. In the Malpighian layer, neutrophils may accumulate to form the characteristic spongiform pustules of Kogoj. questions.text: A young woman had been to a beach for vacation. The next day, she developed the following skin lesions which were very itchy. On examination, the lesions are raised. There were no lesions on the face. She avoided sun exposure for the next 4-5 days and the lesions disappeared. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of raised itchy skin lesions that occur after sun exposure but spare the face and disappear after avoiding sun exposure is suggestive of polymorphic light eruptions. 

It is a recurrent, delayed‐type hypersensitivity (type IV) to sunlight (or artificial ultraviolet rays source) that resolves without scarring. Itchy eruptions appear hours after exposure to the sun. If the patient is exposed to the sun in mid-day, lesions might appear in the night or the following day. Sparing of the face and dorsal aspect of hands is usually seen. This is due to tolerance induced by repeated perennial ultraviolet radiation exposure. On avoiding sun exposure, the lesions disappear within days to weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Sunburn usually presents as painful erythema. It may occur in any sun-exposed areas like the face, hands, etc. It resolves in three to seven days. Scaling, desquamation, and tanning can be seen four to seven days after exposure.

Option B: Heat contact urticaria is one of the rarest forms of inducible urticaria. Localized warming of skin at temperatures from 38 to 44°C for 2–5 min induces wealing at the test site. It usually lasts for an hour.

Option C: In solar urticaria, weals develop within minutes of exposure to sunlight. On avoiding the sun, they disappear within 2 hours.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of multiple discharging sinuses for the past 6 months as shown in the image below. Parents say the lesions started as bluish swellings that ulcerated later. Mantoux test showed an induration measuring 30 mm at 72 hours. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a 6-year-old child, with a history of multiple discharging sinuses for the past 6 months which started as a bluish swelling that ulcerated to form the multiple swellings and sinuses as shown in the image above and with a positive Mantoux test, is suggestive of scrofuloderma. 

Scrofuloderma is the result of a cutaneous infection adjacent to a tuberculous focus due to direct invasion of the tubercle bacillus into the skin. Usually, the lymph nodes, breast, testes, lacrimal gland or duct, infected bone or joint are involved. It commonly occurs in children.

The clinical picture is characterized by asymptomatic, bluish-red subcutaneous, painless, slowly growing nodules that evolve into ulcers and fistulous tracts with drainage of serous, purulent, or caseous content. Fungal tumours can develop from excessive granulation tissue. Sporotrichoid spread can also be seen. The infection site is marked by a distinctive puckered scar after healing.

A skin biopsy taken from the edge of the sinus or ulcer demonstrates the tubercle bacillia and the Mantoux test is usually positive.

Other options

Option A: Lupus vulgaris originates from an underlying focus of tuberculosis, typically in a bone, joint, or lymph node, or maybe from the hematogenous and lymphatic spread. It presents as a slowly enlarging plaque with an elevated border and central atrophy. The edges of the lesion gradually extend in some areas and heal with scarring in others. Apple jelly nodules are demonstrated on diascopy.


Option C: Lichen scrofulosorum is a type of tuberculid. It occurs due to hypersensitivity to the active tubercular infection. They appear as closely grouped lichenoid papules. The lesions are usually skin colored and are often perifollicular. The papule may have an adherent crust or small pustule.


Option D: Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis is caused by exogenous inoculation of M. tuberculosis into the skin through open wounds or abrasions. Lesions appear at the site of inoculation. They appear as verrucous plaque which extends with a serpiginous outline with finger‐like projections. The centre of the lesion may have a white atrophic scar.

questions.text: Your friend asks your advice for acne on her face. On examination, you see that there are around 2-3 small papulopustular acne along with some comedonal acne on her cheek. There are no deep-seated nodules. What will you advise her?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, your friend has papulopustular acne and comedonal acne localized to the cheek. There are no deep-seated nodules. It is mild acne. Mild papulopustular acne has to be treated with topical retinoid and topical antimicrobial. Topical clindamycin is commonly used. 

Types of acne

  • Comedonal acne- these are non-inflammatory dome-shaped papules having open or closed comedones.
  • Papulopustular acne- They are inflammatory and consist of papules and pustules are usually less than 5mm in diameter.
  • Nodular acne- They are also inflammatory nodular lesions that are more than 5mm in diameter.

Mild acne- Inflammatory of noninflammatory lesions in a localized area.

Mild to moderate pustular acne- Extensive papulopustular lesions frequently in association with non‐inflammatory lesions.

Severe acne- Deep-seated lesions consisting of deep-seated nodules, deep-seated pustules, exudative sinus tracts, and scarring. It also involves acne conglabata which has multiple grouped comedones, interspersed with papules, tender inflammatory nodules of varying sizes some of which are suppurative and coalesce to form sinus tracts.

Management-

  • Mild comedonal acne is treated with topical retinoid. Mild papular and pustular acne is treated with topical retinoid and topical antibiotic.
  • Moderate papular/pustular acne and moderate nodular acne are treated with oral antibiotic + topical retinoid with or without benzoyl peroxide. 
  • Severe nodular and conglobate acne are treated with oral irotretinoin.

questions.text: A young woman presents with itchy skin lesions on her wrists. On examination, purple, polygonal, plaques are seen on the wrist. The lesions have a thin white line on their surface. On examination of the oral cavity, the following finding is seen. Which of the following is seen on the microscopy?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the image showing thin white lines on the oral mucosa known as Wickham striae are suggestive of lichen planus. Microscopy will show the presence of colloid bodies.

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membrane. Microscopy will show acanthosis of the epidermis, irregular thickening of the granular layer, and compact hyperkeratosis.  Degenerating basal epidermal cells are transformed into colloid bodies. The rete ridges may have the sawtooth appearance, and focal separation from the dermis may lead to Max-Joseph spaces. In active LP, a band‐like infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes is seen near the dermo-epidermal junction.

Patients present with pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules. The lesions have thin, white lines on their surface known as Wickham striae. They are commonly seen on the volar aspect of the wrists, the lumbar region, and around the ankles.

Mucosal involvement is also seen. The commonest mucosal sites are buccal mucosa and tongue, rarely it can also be found on the anus and genitalia. 

Nail involvement can be seen as thinning of the nail plate, leading to an exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions. The nails can also be destroyed leading to anonychia. Involvement of the nail bed may give rise to longitudinal melanonychia, hyperpigmentation, subungual hyperkeratosis, or onycholysis.

Other options:

Option A - Burrow of mite is seen in scabies. The patients will have skin lesions that are very itchy and worse at night. The family members will also have similar complaints. It is commonly present in the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, the elbows, the axillae, the buttocks and genitalia, and women's breasts.

Option B - Munro microabscess is the accumulation of neutrophils in the stratum corneum. The lesions present as red scaly plaques, which are well demarcated from the surrounding normal skin. They might have a circle of clear zone around it, which is known as the Woronoff ring. 

Option C - Tear-shaped microconidia are seen in tinea corporis, which is commonly caused due to Trichophyton rubrum. The lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge. There might be a similar history in the close contacts.

questions.text: A young woman presents to the gynaecologist with a history of foul-smelling vaginal discharge for the past 5 days. It is associated with vaginal pain and urinary frequency. On examination, frothy discharge can be seen in the vagina. Examination of the cervix shows the following finding. How will you treat this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of frothy foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge with the image showing a strawberry cervix are suggestive of trichomoniasis. It is treated with a 2g orally single dose of metronidazole.

Trichomoniasis is a common parasitic infection that usually occurs in the second and third decades. It is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. Transmission is usually by sexual intercourse, with an incubation period of 4–21 days. 

Patients present with the copious frothy foul-smelling discharge with vaginal soreness or irritation and urinary frequency.

The diagnosis is usually easily confirmed by examination of a wet film by phase-contrast or dark‐field microscopy. The organism can be cultured on Feinberg–Whittington medium.

Standard treatment is with a single metronidazole 2 g oral dose.

Patients should avoid sexual contact for 7 days since the last antibiotic dose, regardless of the treatment given.

The below image shows a strawberry vagina seen in trichomoniasis.

Other options:

Option A- Topical clotrimazole is used in the treatment of vulvovaginal candidosis. It is common during pregnancy and premenstrual periods. It has a thick, curdy discharge. On examination, the vagina and vulva are erythematous and thick curdy discharge is seen.

Options C or D- Doxycycline and azithromycin are used in the treatment of chlamydial infection. They may present with postcoital or intermenstrual bleeding, lower abdominal pain, vaginal discharge and dysuria. Typically, there are signs of mucopurulent cervicitis and/or contact bleeding in such patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with facial redness as shown in the image. He also complains of burning and tingling sensation on the skin which increases on sunlight exposure and wind. The redness of the lesion increases when he consumes hot and spicy beverages and alcohol.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows erythema and papules on the central face, which along with a history of triggering factors like sunlight, wind, spicy food, and alcohol points towards a diagnosis of acne rosacea.

Acne rosacea is a disorder that appears mainly in people within 30 to 50 years of age. The lesions are mainly present on the convexities of the face. There are mainly 4 subtypes:

  • Erythematotelangiectatic rosacea (ETTR): Patients complain of a gradual increase in facial redness. They mainly appear on the lateral cheeks, the ears, and sometimes the sides of the neck. This redness can be triggered by various factors like sunlight, wind, hot, spicy food, and alcohol.
  • Papulopustular rosacea (PPR): Patients complain of red bumps or pimples that are located principally on the proximal cheeks, central chin, nose, and central forehead
  • Phymatous rosacea (PR): Occurs in a patient with preexisting PPR. They complain of thickening of the distal nose with a prominence of pores.
  • Ocular rosacea (OR): Patients complain of dryness and gritty sensation in the eye.

Other options:

Option B- Acne vulgaris is commonly seen in adolescents. It is commonly seen in the face, but can also be present on the back and chest. The lesions may present as comedonal acne, papulopustular acne, nodular acne, etc.

 

Option C- Melasma is seen mainly in women. It manifests as hyperpigmented macules which are mainly seen in the upper lip, the malar regions, the forehead, and the chin and may be associated with the darkening of the nipples. The affected skin is brown in color. They are bilateral and symmetrical.

Option D- Systemic lupus erythematosus presents as cutaneous erythema on light‐exposed areas. It is a butterfly-shaped rash on the cheeks. The nasolabial folds are spared.

questions.text: A baby is brought to the hospital with the following lesions on the body. The lesion started 2 days ago and has increased in number. Similar lesions are also present on the lower limbs. Examination of the oral cavity shows similar lesions. Which of the following infections most commonly presents with this skin condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows target lesions, which are seen in erythema multiforme. Herpes simplex commonly presents with this skin condition.

Erythema multiforme is a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis, which results from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity, most commonly to infection or drugs.

Common triggers of erythema multiforme include: 

  • Herpes simplex infection.
  • Mycoplasma infection.
  • Bacterial infections.
  • Fungal infections.
  • Vaccinations.
  • Malignancy: Carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia.
  • Drug reactions: Sulfonamides, cotrimoxazole, penicillins.
  • Miscellaneous: Lupus erythematosus (Rowell syndrome), sarcoidosis, polyarteritis nodosa.

It presents clinically with macular, popular, or urticarial lesions, along with the classic acral iris or target lesions. The lesions are distributed on the distal extremities, palms or trunk, and oral and genital mucous membranes.

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones:

  • Central area of dusky erythema or purpura.
  • Middle paler zone of edema.
  • Outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Atypical lesions will have only 2 zones. They fade in 1–2 weeks, leaving dusky discoloration.

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Hematoma

A localized tumor‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in color from the surrounding skin. It can be of any color or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is <1 cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate hemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion >1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of edema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumor

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <1 cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >1 cm in diameter
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5 cm. Some authors define nodules as >1 cm.

questions.text:
The given image illustrates a therapeutic modality for certain skin conditions. Which of the following diseases cannot be treated by this therapy?
  1. Psoriasis
  2. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  3. Vitiligo
  4. Dermatomyositis
  5. Dysplastic naevus syndrome
questions.solution:
The given image shows phototherapy being used as a treatment modality. It cannot be used in the treatment of systemic lupus erythematosus, dermatomyositis, and dysplastic naevus syndrome. On the contrary, they are absolute contraindications for phototherapy.

Phototherapy is a form of treatment where nonionizing radiations, commonly ultraviolet radiation are used on the skin. It can be in the form of 

1. UVB- Ultraviolet B rays are the rays that have wavelengths between 280 and 320 nm. If all these wavelengths are used it is called a full spectrum. If only 311–313 nm is used, then it is called narrow-band UVB. It has anti‐inflammatory, immunosuppressive, and cytotoxic properties. The use of UVB does not require the wearing of any photoprotective gear. It can be used for thin plaque and macules, and in pregnancy, and in people with liver diseases.

2. UVA-Ultraviolet A are radiations that have wavelengths between 320 and 400 nm. It is usually used in combination with a psoralen photosensitizer, either orally or topically (PUVA). It acts by cross‐linking of DNA by psoralen photoadducts, inhibition of DNA replication, Langerhans cell depletion, immunosuppressive effects on T‐lymphocyte function and migration, and the restoration of Th17/ regulatory T-cell imbalance in psoriasis. It is used in lesions refractory to UVB, thick plaques, palmoplantar disease, nail disease, etc. 

3. Photopheresis involves the addition of psoralen to the patient’s white blood cells after they have been separated from whole blood ex vivo. The photoactivated white blood cells are then irradiated with UVA and reinfused back into the patient. It is used in the treatment of the erythrodermic stage of cutaneous T‐cell lymphoma, graft‐versus‐host‐disease, etc

Common diseases where phototherapy is used are:

  • Psoriasis
  • Atopic eczema
  • Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma
  • Vitiligo
  • Polymorphic light eruption
  • Lichen planus, etc

Absolute contraindications of phototherapy:

  • Dysplastic naevus syndrome
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Genetic skin cancer syndromes (xeroderma pigmentosum, Gorlin syndrome)
  • Bloom syndrome, Cockayne syndrome

questions.text: A young lady who is a known case of hypothyroidism comes to you with complaints of hair loss. On examination, there is a 2 cm area of complete, smooth, and circular hair loss with distinct margins. Some hairs are broken and are easily extractable. There is no scaling or inflammation present in and around the area of hair loss. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?

choices.text: Mainly affects white and grey hairs
Stippled pitting of nails can be seen

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of alopecia areata.  This disease does not affect white hair.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease. It is associated with several autoimmune diseases including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis.

It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis).

The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. Some broken hairs can be seen which are called exclamation marks. They are easily extractable. It affects pigmented hair and spares white hair. It can cause fine stippled pitting of the nails and roughening of the nail bed, which is called trachyonychia.

Histopathology will show perifollicular and intrafollicular T-lymphocyte infiltration.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of the patients. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. A depot steroid-like triamcinolone administered by fine-needle injection into the upper subcutis can stimulate hair growth at the site. Multiple injections are usually required.

Severe and long-standing alopecia areata requires oral corticosteroids.

questions.text: A young man visits a doctor with a history of bluish-brown discoloration around the eyes. It has been present for the past year. There is no history of any eye injury or road traffic accident. He does not complain of any pain over the discoloration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows bluish-brown pigmentation around the eye. The most likely diagnosis is the naevus of Ota. 

Naevus of Ota is a dermal melanocytosis that mainly affects the sclera and skin around the eyes. These are generally distributed along the ophthalmic and maxillary divisions of the trigeminal nerve. Extracutaneous lesions may be seen in the uveal tract, nasopharynx, palate, and tympanum. They are managed with Q-switched lasers.

Other options:

Option A- Mongolian spots are seen in infants. They are bluish-grey pigmented areas, commonly seen over the sacrum. They usually resolve during childhood.

The image below shows Mongolian spots.

 

Option B- Naevus of Ito is a unilateral hyperpigmentation in the acromioclavicular region and upper chest. It is usually present in the area innervated by the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves.

The image below shows the naevus of Ito.

Option C- Becker's naevus is a hyperpigmented nonlinear lesion commonly present over the upper trunk. It is common in men and appears within the first 2 decades. The lesion is frequently hypertrichotic.

The below image shows Becker's naevus.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with progressive, irregular hypopigmented areas over her scalp as shown. The lesions initially started as flaking which later progressed to hypopigmentation. She has been using hair dye for the past 3-4 years. Examination reveals no blisters or erythema. Patch testing is positive. Which of the following chemicals would have been responsible for this condition?

choices.text: Crocein scarlet MOO and solvent yellow 3

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts that the patient has hypopigmentation due to contact with a hair dye. The chemical that is responsible for this is p-phenylenediamine (PPD).

Contact of the skin to certain chemicals may lead to the development of hypopigmented areas in the corresponding areas of the skin. This is called the chemical leukoderma.

questions.text: A young female visits doctor for the following skin lesion in her ear. It started around 2 years ago and has increased in size gradually. She does not give any history of ear piercings. A biopsy of the tumor was performed and it showed a jigsaw puzzle appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the biopsy showing jigsaw puzzle appearance is diagnostic of cylindroma.

This is a skin tumor that arises from the sweat gland. The lesions are familial and occur due to the mutation of the cylindromatosis gene, CYLD.

The tumors appear as multiple, smooth, firm, pink to red in color, and pedunculated. It is mostly seen on the scalp and adjacent skin. These tumors are benign in nature. 

Histopathology will show the tumor lobules arranged in the form of a jigsaw puzzle. They have a thick basal membrane.

It is treated with wide excision and replacement of the area by a graft.

Below image shows the jigsaw puzzle appearance seen in cylindroma.


Other options

Option A- Basal cell carcinoma commonly occurs in head and neck. They are usually small, translucent or pearly, with raised telangiectatic edges.It has proliferating atypical basaloid cells forming an axis parallel to the epidermal surface. Typical features include palisading of the basal cells.

Below image shows basal cell carcinoma. The cells at the periphery are arranged in palisades.

 


Option C- Hidradenoma is the tumor of the sweat gland. The lesions are usually solitary and are most likely to be found on the scalp, face, anterior trunk, and upper limbs. Rare sites include the vulva, breast, and external ear. It is lobulated and has two cell types. Polygonal clear cells and smaller darker cells. 

Below image is hidradenoma of vulva


Option D- Spiradenoma is a benign tumor of the sweat gland. It is commonly seen in front of the trunk and upper limbs. The lesion is usually solitary and painful and consists of a firm rounded bluish dermal nodule. The tumor is lobular and contains larger pale cells around the lumina and smaller darker cells at the periphery.

questions.text: An elderly female patient visits a doctor with complaints of difficulty in climbing stairs for the past 7 months. She also says that she has difficulty lifting her arms while brushing her hair and getting up from a chair. On examination, the doctor noted that the patient had an erythematous rash over her eyelids, neck, and shoulder. She says that the rash is present for the past 1 year. This finding on her neck and shoulder is known as
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, an elderly woman is presenting with a history of proximal muscle weakness along with erythematous rash over her eyelids, neck, and shoulders. The diagnosis is dermatomyositis. The erythematous rash over the neck and shoulders is called the Shawl sign.

Dermatomyositis as the name suggests involves skin and muscle. It is characterized by proximal muscle weakness along with erythematous rash.

The cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis are as follows:

  • Heliotrope rash- erythematous discoloration of eyelids with periorbital edema
  • Gottron sign- erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles.
  • Gottron papules- raised erythematous rash over knuckles
  • V sign- rash on the sun-exposed anterior neck and chest
  • Shawl sign- rash over neck and shoulders
  • Flagellate erythema- multiple, red, macular streaks occurring on the trunk and proximal limbs
  • Mechanic's hand- non‐inflammatory hyperkeratosis occurring on the hands or feet, usually over the radial surfaces of the fingers and the outer border of the feet
  • Nail bed telangiectasia
  • Subcutaneous calcium deposits

questions.text: A 6-month-old male child is brought to the pediatrician because he has developed large thick dark brown scales on the trunk, hands, and legs. The mother says that the child had fine scaling of the skin immediately after birth, but it resolved on its own. The child was born by Cesarian section because there was insufficient cervical dilation for normal vaginal delivery. Palms and soles appear normal. On examination, the child also has cryptorchidism. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of X-linked recessive ichthyosis.

It occurs due to the deficiency of steroid sulphatase enzyme. The condition mainly affects boys. The mothers of the baby have birth complications like ineffective cervical dilation. The babies may have fine scales on the skin immediately after birth which resolves on their own. At the age of 2-6 months, the babies will develop dark large grey scales on the trunk, extremities, and neck. These dark scales give it a "dirty look".The antecubital folds, popliteal folds, palms, and soles remain unaffected. 

Other findings that can be seen in a patient with X-linked recessive ichthyosis are deep corneal opacity, cryptorchidism, autism, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder syndrome.

It is treated with moisturizers like creams containing glycerols, urea, or up to 12% lactic acid. 

Image: Dirty brown hyperkeratoses over trunk.

Other options:

Option A- Ichthyosis vulgaris (IV) occurs due to filaggrin mutations. Majority of the babies present by the first 3 months of age. They have light grey scales covering mainly the extensor surfaces of the extremities and the trunk. The scales are lighter and smaller than X-linked recessive ichthyosis. It does not affect the flexural areas. Almost all IV patients exhibit accentuated palmar creases.

Option B- Collodion baby ichthyosis has a typical history of having a shiny parchment‐like membrane during birth. This membrane usually peels off within the first 4 weeks of life. They may also have associated ectropion and everted lips. 

Option D- Harlequin ichthyosis is a lethal type of ichthyosis. Neonates are born with armor-like skin. It can be so severe that the babies might have difficulty in breathing and drinking. Bilateral ectropion and eclabium are also present. The majority of the babies die due to breathing difficulty.

questions.text: Azathioprine, which is used in the treatment of systemic lupus erythematosus and dermatomyositis, acts by inhibiting
questions.solution:
Azathioprine acts by inhibiting purine synthesis. It is a purine analog and hampers the synthesis of purine. It is found to be antiproliferative, antiinflammatory, and immunosuppressant. 

It is a prodrug which is rapidly transformed into 6-marcaptopurine (6-MP).

It is used in the treatment of:

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Immunobullous diseases (in particular pemphigus and pemphigoid)
  • Atopic eczema
  • Chronic actinic dermatitis.

It is excreted through the kidneys and the GIT. There is no enterohepatic circulation. The dose should be reduced in cases of impaired renal function.

It should be avoided in breastfeeding women.

Important adverse effects of azathioprine are:

  • Myelosuppression
  • Development of lymphomas and squamous cell carcinomas
  • Increased risk of disseminated herpes simplex, varicella-zoster virus, and human papillomavirus infections
  • Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea
  • Mild derangement of liver function tests
  • Hypersensitivity to the drug

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought to the hospital with multiple pruritic, small papules on the extensor surface along with lesions as shown in the below image. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this disease?

choices.text: Tense Blisters and vesicles can be seen.
Granular deposition of IgA at DEJ identified by direct immunofluorescence.
Target antigen is BP180 or BPAg2
Perioral and perianal lesions are frequently seen in young children.

questions.solution:
The given clinical features along with an image showing a string of pearl appearance, are suggestive of Chronic Bullous Disorder of Childhood or Linear IgA Disease. The diagnostic hallmark is the linear deposition of IgA deposits at DEJ identified by direct immunofluorescence.

Chronic Bullous Disorder of Childhood (CBDC), is an immunobullous disease of childhood, which clinically present as an annular arrangement of vesicles.

  • Tense Blisters, vesicles, and annular erythema are the characteristic triad of clinical features.
  • The blisters are arranged in a circular fashion, hence called crown of jewels, the cluster of jewels, or string of pearls appearance.
  • In young children, the distribution of lesions is perioral, perianal, and in the perineum.
  • Target antigen is BP180 or BPAg2 >> BP230 or BPAg1.

Patterns seen on Direct Immunofluorescence in Vesiculobullous disorders are

  1. Linear Pattern (shore-line fluorescence pattern)
  • Due to linear IgG and C3 deposits along the DermoEpidermal Junctions (DEJ): Bullous Pemphigoid, Cicatricial Pemphigoid, Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita.
  • Due to linear deposits of IgA at DEJ: Linear IgA dermatosis

2. Focal granular deposits of IgA at papillary tips seen in Dermatitis herpetiformis

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with the following condition of toenails. The discoloration  spread proximally as a streak in the nail and later the entire nail was affected. Gradually, the entire nail became brittle and separated from the nailbed. What can be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the image of the affected nail, points to a diagnosis of Tinea unguium.

Tinea unguium or onychomycosis is defined as the infection of the nail plate by fungus. Trichophyton rubrum accounts for most cases, but many other fungi may be causative.

Clinically, yellowish discoloration occurs, which spreads proximally as a streak in the nail. Later, subungual hyperkeratosis becomes prominent and spreads until the entire nail is affected. Gradually, the entire nail becomes brittle and separated from its bed as a result of the piling up of subungual keratin.

Six distinct patterns of tinea unguium have been described:

  • Distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis (DLSO) - Most common form
  • Superficial onychomycosis (SO)
  • Proximal subungual onychomycosis
  • Endonyx onychomycosis
  • Totally dystrophic onychomycosis
  • Mixed onychomycosis

Diagnosis is made by KOH mount examination of clippings or curettings that include dystrophic subungual debris.

Mild infections affecting the distal nail plate only or non‐linear superficial onychomycosis are treated topically with amorolfine or ciclopirox olamine 

Oral terbinafine is the treatment of choice for Tinea unguium or onychomycosis. Oral Terbinafine at 250 mg/day is given for a duration of 6 weeks for fingernail infection and 3 months (12 weeks)  for toenail infection.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with headache, fever and vomiting. He is -2 SD below the normal weight for age and both his parents work as labourers. On examination, multiple small vesicles are present on the posterior pharyngeal wall as shown in the image.  What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis is characterized by the presence of ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces, or palate or uvula, and the posterior pharyngeal wall as shown in the image. 

Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis is a common clinical manifestation of coxsackie A infection (a large subgroup of the enteroviruses) in children, but it can also be caused by Coxsackievirus B virus, echoviruses, or enterovirus 71. The lesions are small vesicles on the fauces and the posterior pharyngeal wall that break down to form ulcers. 

Treatment is usually supportive only, as the disease is self-limiting and usually runs its course in less than a week. 

 

Other options:

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterised by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs. Vesicles heal without crusting, which clinically differentiates them from the vesicles of herpesviruses and poxviruses. The most common enteroviruses causing this syndrome worldwide are Enterovirus 71 (EV71), Coxsackie A6 (CA6), Coxsackie A16 (CA16), and Coxsackie A10 (CA10). It is usually a benign illness resolving in 1-2 weeks.

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby presented with loss of developmental milestones, hypotonia, seizures, failure to thrive, and has a characteristic cherubic appearance with a depressed nasal bridge. The microscopic appearance of his hair strand is given below. What is the most likely cause of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given image shows pili torti seen in Menke's syndrome or Tricholipodystrophy or Steely hair disease which is an X‐linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in ATP7A, which encodes for a copper-transporting ATPase‐α polypeptide.

Copper is an essential co‐factor for several metalloenzymes in the human body, including tyrosinase and lysyl oxidase. The primary manifestation of acquired copper deficiency is a myeloneuropathy that affects both sensory and motor nerves.

Hair changes can be the first sign of disease at 1–2 months of age. Scalp and eyebrow hair resemble steel wool, appearing short, sparse, lustreless, tangled and depigmented. Pili torti is the classic finding on trichogram.

At 2–3 months of age, children with Menkes disease present with loss of developmental milestones, hypotonia, seizures, and failure to thrive. These infants have a characteristic cherubic appearance with a depressed nasal bridge, pudgy cheeks, ‘cupids bow’ upper lip and doughy skin.

For Menkes disease, if treatment is initiated during the neonatal period or early infancy, neurological deterioration can be halted.

Nutritional deficiencies may cause the following:

  • Zinc deficiency: Hair is dry and brittle, and large areas of alopecia may arise.
  • Keshan's disease: Selenium deficiency presents as brittle hair and may be associated with exfoliative dermatitis on the scalp.
  • Kwashiorkor: Hair develops a lustreless, red‐brown color that may show alternation with more normal color; this so‐called ‘flag sign’ corresponds to alternating periods of significant undernutrition and improved nutrition.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A young female approached for your advice regarding the advice for the maintenance of her hair health. On examination you find her scalp and hair are normal, most of her hair you notice will be in the ______ stage of the hair cycle.
questions.solution:
Under normal conditions, about 80-90% of hair follicles at a given time are in the anagen phase.

Hair follicles undergo a repetitive sequence of growth and the rest, it is known as the hair cycle. Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: anagen, catagen, and telogen.

Anagen :

  • The period of active hair growth is known as anagen and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair.
  • The entry of a resting hair follicle into anagen is heralded by the onset of mitotic activity in epithelial cells overlying the dermal papilla at the base of the follicle (the secondary epithelial germ).
  • Under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen at any one time.
  • Anagen can continue for several years.
  • It can be identified by the presence of an angulated root.

2. Catagen

  • At the end of anagen, epithelial cell division declines and ceases, and the follicle enters an involutionary phase known as catagen.
  • During catagen, the proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle involutes by apoptosis. Clubbing is first seen in catagen and becomes more prominent in telogen phase.
  • It lasts for about 3 weeks.

3. Telogen

  • It is the time period between catagen and the next anagen.
  • It lasts for about 3 months.
  • Club hair is eventually shed through an active process called exogen.
  • In the human scalp, hair follicles may remain in a state of latency, also known as kenogen, for a pro­longed period after the club hair is shed.

questions.text: An adolescent girl presents to you with lesions on her face. She confides in you that she frequently picks the real or imagined acne from her face and does this when she is under stress. The term used for this self-inflicted skin condition is called:
questions.solution:
Acne excoriée is a self-inflicted skin condition, in which the sufferer compulsively picks real or imagined acne lesions predominantly on the face. It is predominantly seen in adolescent girls. 

Other psychiatric disorders associated with acne are:

  • Body dysmorphic disorder: A small number of patients with BDD have acne as their prime symptom. The perceived acne is out of proportion to physical signs.
  • Eating disorders: Acne has been reported in anorexia nervosa. Acne itself may be a predisposing factor for anorexia in vulnerable teenage age groups who adopt a diet in an attempt to control their acne. 

Other options:

Option B: Acne mechanica: This term describes acneform lesions that occur at the site of repeated mechanical trauma and/or frictional obstruction of the pilosebaceous outlet. Examples include mechanical pressure from high‐necked jerseys, shoulder pads, seat backs in trucks, or adhesive plasters causing acneform folliculitis.

Option C: Acne conglobata: Acne conglobata represents a rare and severe form of acne characterized by multiple and extensive inflammatory papules, tender nodules, and abscesses which commonly coalesce to form malodorous draining sinus tracts.

Option D: Acne fulminans: Acne fulminans or acne maligna is a rare and severe destructive form of acne presenting primarily in adolescent males. It most frequently affects the trunk but can affect the face. It presents acutely in association with systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scales mostly over the upper trunk and thighs accompanied with light itching. The scales were arranged in a christmas tree pattern in the upper back. What could be the most possible diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is pityriasis rosea, which has typical collarette scales. A collarette scale is a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion.

Pityriasis rosea is an acute self-limiting disease, probably infective in origin, affecting mainly children and young adults. It is characterized by a distinctive skin eruption and minimal constitutional symptoms.

It is also called pityriasis circinata et maculata of Vidal.

The first manifestation of the disease is usually the appearance of the herald patch. Christmas tree pattern along lines cleavage with the peripheral collarette of scale producing the hanging curtain sign when stretched.

Note: Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated stratum corneum.

questions.text: Leukemia cutis is most commonly seen in association with which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Leukemia cutis is most common in patients with myeloid neoplasms, especially acute myeloid leukemia (AML). The risk is higher with translocation t(8,21).

Leukemia cutis is an infiltration of the skin by myeloid or lymphoid neoplastic leukocytes resulting in clinically identifiable cutaneous lesions. When made up of malignant granulocytic precursor cells, leukemia cutis lesions are also called myeloid sarcoma, granulocytic sarcoma, or chloroma.

Leukemia cutis typically presents as single or multiple monomorphic violaceous, dark‐red or hemorrhagic skin nodules and plaques, especially on the legs, arms, and face.

questions.text: The pattern of DEJ causing pointy rete pegs, as shown in the histopathology image below, is most likely to be suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given histopathology picture shows saw toothing as seen in lichen planus.

Saw toothing: This refers to an alteration in the pattern of the dermal–epidermal junction where dermal papillae are expanded and the tips of the rete pegs are pointed. The resulting pattern bears a superficial resemblance to the teeth of a saw and the change is seen in lichen planus and other lichenoid reactions.

Papillamatosis: This change is characterized by upward elongation of the dermal papillae, giving an accentuated and sometimes irregular, undulating configuration to the dermal–epidermal junction. The feature is commonly seen in psoriasis, and a wide variety of other inflammatory and neoplastic cutaneous disorders.

Parakeratosis: Parakeratosis can be defined as the retention of keratinocyte nuclei within stratum corneum. It represents a disturbance of keratinization. It is commonly seen in Psoriasis.

Spongiosis - refers to intercellular edema or intrapidermal fluid. It is characteristically seen in acute or subacute eczematous reaction.

questions.text: An elderly lady presented with the following skin lesions on the face. They do not cause any symptoms except for cosmetic appearance. She is concerned as they have increased in number over the years. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The finding seen in the case scenario provided is seborrheic keratosis.

Seborrheic keratoses are common epidermal tumors consisting of a benign proliferation of immature keratinocytes. They present as well-demarcated plaques or papules, round, or oval lesions with a dull, verrucous surface and a typical stuck-on appearance. They are usually multiple. They typically occur on the chest and back but are also found commonly on the face, scalp, neck, and extremities. These lesions can be easily removed with liquid nitrogen or curettage or both.

Other options:

Option B- Malignant melanoma is a malignant proliferation of melanocytes. It is usually solitary unlike multiple in this case. Moreover, it is fast-growing, has color changes, and asymmetrical appearance. In case of doubt, a biopsy can be done.

Option C- Dermatosis papulosa nigra are smaller flat lesions limited to the upper part of the face. They usually occur after the 2nd decade unlike so late as in this case.

Option D- Verrucae vulgaris refers to benign warts. They have a cauliflower-like warty surface, unlike a smooth surface as in this case.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to your OPD with lesions as shown below. The parent says he also had similar lesions in childhood. The lesions are present on the forearm, face, and flexures and are very itchy on the background of dry skin showing signs of lichenification. Grattage test or scratching reveals oozing of serous fluid. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Image showing eczematous lesions on the forearm, and flexures. This along with the history of them being very itchy and being located on the dry skin showing signs of lichenification and a grattage test revealing oozing of serous fluid points towards atopic dermatitis as the likely diagnosis.

Atopic dermatitis can be divided into 3 phases: Infantile, childhood, and adult phases.

Infantile phase: The lesions of Atopic Eczema most frequently start on the face but may occur anywhere on the skin surface. Often, the napkin area is relatively spared.

  • When the child begins to crawl, the exposed surfaces, especially the extensor aspect of the knees and elbows are most involved.
  • The lesions consist of erythema and discrete or confluent oedematous papules. The papules are intensely itchy and may become exudative and crusted as a result of rubbing.
  • Secondary infection and lymphadenopathy are common.

Childhood Phase: From 18 to 24 months onwards, the sites most characteristically involved are the elbow and knee flexures, a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper‐ and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification may be seen depending on the skin type on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles.

  • The sides of the neck may show a striking reticulate pigmentation, sometimes referred to as atopic dirty neck.
  • The erythematous and oedematous papules tend to be replaced by lichenification.

Adult Phase: The picture is essentially similar to that in later childhood, with lichenification, especially of the flexures and hands.

Other options:

Option A: Lichen simplex chronicus usually presents as an itchy plaque. Chronic itching produces secondary lichenification. It may be associated with the history of atopy. It is less likely to appear as oozing on scratching. A predilection for flexural aspect in childhood as in this case is not classically seen.

Option B: Psoriasis classically involves extensor aspect unlike flexures as in this child. Moreover, it is associated with silvery scaling and grattage reveals fresh bleeding points (Auspitz sign) and not oozing of serous fluid.

Option D: Scabies is caused by itch mites laying eggs in burrows made in the skin. The burrows are visible as serpiginous erythematous lesions. It classically causes itching more during the evening and involves lesions in the circle of hebra unlike flexures as in this case.

Related Pearl: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

  • Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presented to you during your rural posting as a part of a routine checkup camp to show the lesions as below. The red papular lesions do not cause him any discomfort and have been present for 6 months. His spot blood sugar is 300mg/dl. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given maculopapular lesions on the shins along with uncontrolled blood sugar point towards a diagnosis of diabetic dermopathy.

Diabetic dermopathy:

  • It presents as asymptomatic, oval, dull‐red papules 0.5–1 cm in diameter that evolve slowly on the shins, forearms, thighs, and over bony prominences, producing a superficial scale and, ultimately, atrophic brown scars.
  • Binkley's spots or diabetic shin spots is another name for diabetic dermopathy. The phrase diabetic dermopathy was coined by Binkley in 1965.
  • Pathologically, there is hyperpigmentation of the epidermal basal layer, deposition of haemosiderin and melanin in the dermis, and arteriolar basement membrane thickening.
  • Diabetic dermopathy is common and is a marker for complications of diabetes such as retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy.

Other Options:

Option A: Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is a rare chronic and granulomatous skin disorder that is seen in diabetic patients. The most likely etiology is microangiopathy. Most rashes are located on the legs, especially above the tibiae. The patches are initially brown and later may progress to yellow atrophic plaques.

Option C: Granuloma annulare is most commonly found in children and females <30 years. It manifests as groups of 1-2mm papules that range from skin-colored to violaceous, in an annular arrangement over distal extremities. There is no confirmed association with diabetes.

Below image shows granuloma annulare:

Option D: Furuncle/ boil is caused by Staphylococcus. It is painful and usually situated in the neck area. It is pustular and later becomes necrotic and forms a scar.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male complained of burning micturition, multiple joints pains, and red eyes. Reiter's syndrome is suspected. Which of the following cutaneous feature is likely to be associated?
questions.solution:
Keratoderma blennorrhagica is seen associated with Reiter’s syndrome in 10% of cases.

Reiter syndrome is a systemic disorder, originally defined as a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. Cutaneous involvement includes psoriasiform lesions, named keratoderma blennorrhagic um (in about 10%), painful and erosive lesions on the tips of the fingers and toes, nail dystrophy (20-30%) and erythroderma as a rare complication.

In addition, there may be other distinct mucocutaneous manifestations like circinate balanitis, these are small, shallow, painless ulcerative lesions on the glans penis.

questions.text: In a 20-year-old female who is suffering from chronic urticaria, you notice that the following three phenomenons occur in a sequential manner on stroking her skin. i) Redness in the line of stroke, ii) edema, and iii) Spread of redness around the line of stoke. These events are also associated with severe itching. What is this pattern of dermographism?
questions.solution:
The sequential occurrence of these events in a patient with urticaria, associated with itching is suggestive of symptomatic dermographism.

Dermographism is commonly elicited in chronic urticaria patients.

  • Simple dermographism is defined as the triple response of local erythema due to capillary vasodilatation, followed by edema and a surrounding flare due to axon reflex‐induced dilatation of arterioles after stroking the skin.
  • However, in <5%, it is accompanied by severe itching (symptomatic dermographism or factitious urticaria).
  • Patients complain of wealing and itching at sites of trauma, friction with clothing or scratching the skin. The itching is usually disproportionately severe compared with wealing and is often most severe at night. 
  • The eliciting stimulus determines the shape of the weals, but they are often linear from scratching or stroking.

Other forms of dermographism include

  • Red dermographism - repeated rubbing is necessary to induce small punctate weals.
  • Cholinergic dermographism - seen in some patients with cholinergic urticaria. Here, the demographic response consists of an erythematous line studded with punctate weals.
  • Delayed dermographism - after normal fading of the triple response, a weal returns in the same site, but is usually tender and persists for about 48 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Basement Membrane Zone?
questions.solution:
Desmosome is not a component of Basement Membrane Zone.

Basement membrane zone or dermo-epidermal junction is the junction between epidermis and dermis. This zone is composed of 3 components:

  • Hemidesmosome
  • Anchoring Filaments
  • Anchoring Fibrils.

Note: Desmosomes are the major adhesion complex in the epidermis, anchoring keratin intermediate filaments to the cell membrane and bridging adjacent keratinocytes, and allowing cells to withstand trauma.

Related Pearl: Dermoepidermal Junction/Basement Membrane Zone

  • The junction between epidermis and dermis is called the basement membrane zone or dermoepidermal junction and consists of a number of extracellular macromolecules.
  • As many of these components are glycoproteins, the BMZ can be recognized histologically by staining with PAS stain.
  • Ultrastructural examination by electron microscopy shows 2 different layers with different optical densities
    • Lamina Lucida - upper, less electron dense layer
    • Lamina Densa - lower, more electron dense layer
  • This zone is composed of 3 components : 1. Hemidesmosome 2. Anchoring Filaments 3. Anchoring Fibrils.

1.HEMIDESMOSOME

  • Hemidesmosomes are multiprotein complexes that facilitate the stable adhesion of basal epithelial cells to the underlying basement membrane.
  • The intermediate keratin filaments K5/K14 present within the basal keratinocytes attach to the hemidesmosomes at the base of the cell.
  • The major hemidesmosomal Protein is Bullous Pemphigoid Antigen-1 (BPAg1 or BP230) and this attaches to the transmembrane component protein BPAg2 (BP180) below.
  • The other hemidesmosomal protein Plectin is attached to the transmembrane component protein called as α6β4 integrin below.

2.ANCHORING FILAMENTS/Lamina Lucida and Lamina Densa

  • The anchoring filaments form the Lamina Lucida layer.
  • Anchoring filaments consist of Laminin5/332 proteins that connect BPAg2 and α6β4 integrin above to Lamina Densa below.
  • Lamina Densa consists mainly of type IV Collagen and other proteins like Nidogen.  

3.ANCHORING FIBRILS

  • These are ultrastructurally U shaped structures that attach the Lamina Densa above to the underlying connective tissue below in dermis.
  • Type VII Collagen is the major protein in anchoring fibrils.

Blistering disorders in the DEJ/BMZ arise due to defects or antibodies against any of the above mentioned proteins.

questions.text: A 27- year-old female presents with velvety darkish discoloration of the skin around her neck and arm-pits. She doesn’t have any other symptoms. Which of the following is the most commonly associated condition with the observed findings?
questions.solution:
Velvety darkish discoloration of the skin around her neck and arm-pits are suggestive of Acanthosis Nigricans. The most commonly associated condition with it is obesity.

Acanthosis nigricans is a dermatosis that manifests as an asymptomatic and symmetrical darkening of the skin. It is seen in the skin of intertriginous areas, in particular the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck.

Obesity is the most common association with acanthosis nigricans and can regress with weight loss.

questions.text: A patient visited the OPD with multiple, painless masses on his hand as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most common causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows verruca vulgaris or common warts and the most common causative organism of it is HPV-2 (human papilloma virus -2). These common warts are also closely related to HPV 1, 4, 27, and 57.

Viral warts show acanthosis and hyperkeratosis, usually with the characteristic koilocytosis of upper keratinocytes. Most of them also show papillomatosis.

Appearance: Common warts present as firm papules with a rough horny surface.

Site: They can occur anywhere on the skin but most commonly situated on the backs of the hands and fingers. In children they can be seen on the knees. New lesions can also occur along the sites of trauma known as pseudo-Koebner phenomenon.

Usually asymptomatic. 

Management:

  • Salicylic acid with or without lactic acid - first line treatment
  • Cryotherapy - second line treatment

Other options: 

Options A and C: HPV-6 and HPV-11 are associated with anogenital warts and laryngeal papillomas.

Option B: HPV-16 is associated with anogenital warts and cervical carcinoma.

questions.text: A 43-year-old HIV-positive male patient presented with the following finding. The plaque could not be rubbed off. Which virus is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image showing a white corrugated plaque over the lateral border of the tongue in an HIV-infected patient which cannot be rubbed off is suggestive of oral hairy leukoplakia. It is due to the reactivation of Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infection.

questions.text: A patient with an outbreak of cold sores 2 days ago now presents with non-pruritic lesions on his elbow, as seen below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of cold sores, a herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, followed by the appearance of pathognomic target lesions, as seen in the image, is suggestive of erythema multiforme.

Erythema multiforme (EM) is an acute, self-limited, skin condition that is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction associated with certain infections, medications, and other triggers. Precipitating factors commonly include HSV strains 1 and 2, EBV, and drugs like sulfa drugs. This is consistent with the patient history of having had cold sores.

It presents as a localized eruption of the skin with minimal or no mucosal involvement. The papules then evolve into pathognomonic target or iris lesions that appear within a 72-hour period and begin on the extremities. Lesions remain in a fixed location for at least 7 days and then begin to heal.  

Other options:

Option A: Viral exanthem is an eruptive skin rash that is often related to a viral infection. It can have various types of rash based on the virus associated.

Option B: Acute exanthematous pustulosis is associated with drug reaction and presents as small non-follicular pustules on an erythematous base that undergo spontaneous resolution.

Option D: Drug eruptions are cutaneous manifestations that are often related to a drug used. It can have various types of rash based on the drug used.
